solutions.title: python-beats-99-75-with-full-working-explanation
solutions.content:
```
class Solution:
    def reorderList(self, head: Optional[ListNode]) -> None:  # Time: O(n) and Space: O(1)

        # Find Middle: find middle and divide the list in to two
        slow, fast = head, head.next  # head(slow) -> 1 -> 2(fast) -> ...
        while fast and fast.next:     # while fast exists and there is next element to travel keep moving
            slow = slow.next          # fast moving twice as much as slow, will lead slow to point in the middle 
            fast = fast.next.next     # Even(4): slow = 2, fast = 4 & Odd(5): slow = 3, fast = None 

        # Reverse: reverse the second list
        second = slow.next       # in Odd case lets say 1-> 2(slow) -> 3 -> 4(fast): second = 3(2.next) 
        prev = slow.next = None  # Created Two separate nodes 1->2 & 3->4 
        while second:
            tmp = second.next   # tmp = 4
            second.next = prev  # 3 -> None
            prev = second       # prev = 3
            second = tmp        # second = 4
        # So, in the next iteration 
            # tmp = None 
            # 4.next = prev(3) and our linked is reversed
			# prev = 4 
			# second = None

        # Merge: merge the first with the reversed second  
        first, second = head, prev  # first will point to starting of the 1st Node and second to 2nd Node
        while second:
            tmp1, tmp2 = first.next, second.next  # tmp1 = 2, tmp2 = 3
            first.next = second                   # 1 -> 4
            second.next = tmp1                    # 4.next = 2 i.e. 1 -> 4 -> 2 
            first, second = tmp1, tmp2            # first = 2, second = 3
        # So, in the next iteration 
            # tmp1 = tmp2 = None
            # 2 -> 3 i.e. 1 -> 4 -> 2 -> 3
            # 1 -> 4 -> 2 -> 3 -> None
			# first = second = None
```

solutions.content:
It may look long but read through and you'll definitely understand.

**Approach:**
1. Find the middle of the given linked list and create a newlist with the node after the middle node
2. Reverse the new list
3. Now interjoin original list and new list together

For example,
```
List = 1 -> 2 -> 3 -> 4 -> 5
mid = 3
so, 
List = 1 -> 2 -> 3
newList = 4 -> 5
reversedNewList = 5 -> 4
Inter Join List (1 -> 2 -> 3) and reversedNewList (5 -> 4):
1 -> 5 -> 2 -> 4 -> 3
```
```
def reorderList(self, head: Optional[ListNode]) -> None:
	# Find the middle of given linked list
	slow = head
	fast = head

	while fast and fast.next:
		slow = slow.next
		fast = fast.next.next

	newList = slow.next # create a new list with the node after the middle node
	slow.next = None # set next node of middle node to none

	# Reverse the new list
	prev = None
	cur = newList

	while cur:
		nxt = cur.next
		cur.next = prev
		prev = cur
		cur = nxt

	newReversedHead = prev # head of new list

	# Interjoin head and newReversedHead
	node1, node2 = head, newReversedHead
	flag = 1

	while node1 and node2:
		if flag:
			nxt = node1.next
			node1.next = node2
			node1 = nxt
		else:
			nxt = node2.next
			node2.next = node1
			node2 = nxt

		flag = not flag
```

```
def reorderList(self, head: Optional[ListNode]) -> None:
	# Find the middle of given linked list
	slow = head
	fast = head

	while fast and fast.next:
		slow = slow.next
		fast = fast.next.next

	newList = slow.next # create a new list with the node after the middle node
	slow.next = None # set next node of middle node to none

	# Reverse the new list
	prev = None
	cur = newList

	while cur:
		nxt = cur.next
		cur.next = prev
		prev = cur
		cur = nxt

	newReversedHead = prev # head of new list

	# Interjoin head and newReversedHead
	node1, node2 = head, newReversedHead
	flag = 1

	while node1 and node2:
		if flag:
			nxt = node1.next
			node1.next = node2
			node1 = nxt
		else:
			nxt = node2.next
			node2.next = node1
			node2 = nxt

		flag = not flag
```

1. Find the middle by moving fast & slow iterators.
2. Remember right part beginning and cut off left part from the right.
3. Reverse right list, remember it new beginning.
4. Iterate left part from beginning and right part merging right list nodes into left list.

I used the same method, but it is showing error. Could you please provide me with the code, If possible? \nThanks.
I used this approach only.

To be honest, the concepts aren\'t super hard here. But I think the combination of reversal + merging operations during an interview settting makes this problem on the harder end of medium problems. This, coupled with the fact you have to recognize that in order to get the new order, you have to reverse the second half, then merge the two halves. IDK, seems hard to do in 45 minutes. Took me 10 minutes to figure out the pattern, and 40 minutes to code.
I solved it by using O(N) space in O(N) time.
good job \n

I used a stack for this solution to store the 2nd half of the list.\nLater iteratively popped the last node from the stack and inserted it after the current node of the list and progressed until the stack is empty.

I used this approach in first time. I code and pass the tests. But $$O(n)$$  as space complexity... We can do better, right?\nHow?\nAfter about 4 hours, doing some sport exercises, I get the idea: reverse the second part!

What if there are odd number of nodes?

For example:

L: L0

What's the result?

L: L0 -> L0?

I made a special case for odd nodes. If you think about it the very last node will be that middle node.

Example:
L1->L2->L3-L4->L5
wil be
L1->L5->L2->L4->L3
After the stack is empty, make the last node point to NULL to remove this unwanted loop,
I am asking this because I am trying to use stack for my solution. Is it considered in-place ?
that would be using extra space which isn\'t optimal

1. Find the middle by moving fast & slow iterators.
2. Remember right part beginning and cut off left part from the right.
3. Reverse right list, remember it new beginning.
4. Iterate left part from beginning and right part merging right list nodes into left list.
Thanks to this I was able to code it myself, thinking this solution was not easy

[@letsstart2020](/letsstart2020) because without cutting or making the previous pointer of the mid half resulting in making the graph, two pointers pointing the same node, so it will definitely give some pain to the programmer
That\'s of great help without posting solution
Thanks! Step 2 solved my cycles
I did not cut the two lists and was getting time limit exceeded, could you please explain why as i am new to linked list
I used the same method, but it is showing error. Could you please provide me with the code, If possible? \nThanks.
I used this approach only.

To be honest, the concepts aren\'t super hard here. But I think the combination of reversal + merging operations during an interview settting makes this problem on the harder end of medium problems. This, coupled with the fact you have to recognize that in order to get the new order, you have to reverse the second half, then merge the two halves. IDK, seems hard to do in 45 minutes. Took me 10 minutes to figure out the pattern, and 40 minutes to code.
I solved it by using O(N) space in O(N) time.
good job \n

I used a stack for this solution to store the 2nd half of the list.\nLater iteratively popped the last node from the stack and inserted it after the current node of the list and progressed until the stack is empty.

I used this approach in first time. I code and pass the tests. But $$O(n)$$  as space complexity... We can do better, right?\nHow?\nAfter about 4 hours, doing some sport exercises, I get the idea: reverse the second part!
[@deepsym](/deepsym) uski marzi bhai \uD83D\uDE02
I also applied this approach.\n
You could do this with O(1) space complexity.
Input:\t[]\nOutput:\t[]\nExpected:\t{}
i used deque to solve this question .\ni have copied the complete list into deque and iterated it from front and back succesivley

that is not O(1) space complexity tho

Good practice for most of the important techniques of dealing with linked lists, ie. 2 pointer traversing, reversing, merging, ...

This question utilizes the linked list patterns you pick up from doing \'easy\' problems. I got stuck on merging the two lists because if you leave the middle node in both lists then you will create a cycle. Continuing until the reversed lists next is null prevents you from adding the second list node when it already exists at the end of the first list.

Can someone please help - getting TLE on my code with one of the test cases and can't figure why :( 

```
def reorderList(self, head):
        # 1. Find middle of list
        slow = fast = head
        while fast and fast.next:
            slow = slow.next
            fast = fast.next.next     
        
        second = slow.next
        slow.next = None

        # Reverse the second half
        current, previous = second, None
        while current:
            nextNode = current.next
            current.next = previous
            previous = current
            current = nextNode
        second = previous

        # Merge both linked lists:
        node1, node2 = head, second
        while node1 and node2:
            nextNode1 = node1.next
            nextNode2 = node2.next

            node1.next = node2
            node1 = nextNode1

            node2.next = node1
            node2 = nextNode2
```

I have the some problem. It take me time to figure out why I have this cycle?
Drawing help me to understand  what happen.
Take an example:
1 ->  2 ->  3 -> 4 -> null
- stack has: 4 -> null and  3 -> 4 in reversed order
- current is : 1 - > 2 -> 3 -> 4 -> null
In the first iteration:
- next is: 2 -> 3 -> 4 -> null-last is 4 -> null
current.next = last, has as consequence:
head  = 1 -> 4 -> null
next = 2 -> 3 -> 4  -> null
In other hand, last.next = next has as result:
4 -> next
4 -> 2 -> 3 -> 4 -> (nut null but the same ListNode)
and head: 1 -> |  4 -> 2 -> 3 -> 4 |  -> 2 -> 3 -> 4 -> 2 -> 3 -> 4....
I hope that will helpful. And forgive my English!

`# Definition for singly-linked list.
class ListNode(object):
    def __init__(self, val=0, next=None):
        self.val = val
        self.next = next

class Solution(object):
    def reorderList(self, head):
        """
        :type head: ListNode
        :rtype: None Do not return anything, modify head in-place instead.
        """

        nodes_list = []
        insert_cnt = 0

        # get values of node into list 
        while head is not None:
            nodes_list.append(head.val)
            head = head.next 
        # print ("nodes_list", nodes_list)

        # even and odd length arrays 
        if len(nodes_list) % 2 != 0: # odd len array 
            midpt_index = int(len(nodes_list)/2)+1 # +1 to mimic ceiling  
        else: # even len array 
            midpt_index = len(nodes_list)/2

        # print (midpt_index)

        lft_arr = nodes_list[0:midpt_index]
        rt_arr = nodes_list[midpt_index:len(nodes_list)+1]
        rt_arr_rev = list(reversed(rt_arr))

        # print (lft_arr, rt_arr_rev)

        for i, val in enumerate(rt_arr_rev):
            i_insert = i+1 + insert_cnt
            lft_arr.insert(i_insert, val)
            insert_cnt += 1

        # print ("lft_arr", lft_arr)

        # convert list into LL
        newHead = temp = ListNode()

        for val in lft_arr:
            # print ("val", val)
            temp.next = ListNode(val)
            temp = temp.next

        # print ("newHead.next", newHead.next.next.next.next.val)
        return newHead.next`

I don't understand the problem.
If we have an array of words: 

>  ["practice", "makes", "perfect", "coding", "makes"]

then "coding" and "practice" are 2 words apart ("makes" and "perfect"), not 3 like the problem states.
Same as "makes" and "coding" are 1 word apart.

What am I missing?
Yeah. It is comparing indices. Notice that there another "makes" in the dictionary, and there are 0 words apart.

Imagine you are on a straight line:

> |0|1|2|3|4|
> |---|---|---|---|---|
> |practice|makes|perfect|coding|makes|

If you stand at position 0 (`practice`), how many steps you need to walk to get to position 3 (`coding`)?
**Ans =** 3 steps

In other words:

* `coding` is 3 words apart if you are standing on `practice`
* also `practice` is 3 words apart if you are standing on `coding`

This is exactly how you would calculate distance between two points on a number line.
It\'s comparing the indices
